instructions.title: 4 steps to help stop police brutality:

scripts.title: The George Floyd Justice in Policing Act of 2020
scripts.subtitle: The House of Representatives just passed this bill which, "addresses a wide range of policies and issues regarding policing practices and law enforcement accountability". Now it's up to the Senate. Call your Senator and let them know this is an important issue for you.

senate.title: When calling your senator, this can help
senate.paragraph_1_html: Hello, my name is YOUR NAME. I'm a constituent from YOUR CITY, zip code YOUR ZIP CODE. I don't need a response.
senate.paragraph_2_html: I’m very concerned about the ongoing violence police officers are using against civilians and I strongly encourage the senator to vote yes on bill H.R.7120, the "George Floyd Justice in Policing Act of 2020".
senate.paragraph_3: Thank you for your hard work!

quotation.content: Under the doctrine of qualified immunity, public officials are held to a much lower standard. They can be held accountable only insofar as they violate rights that are “clearly established” in light of existing case law.

aboutCongress.imageAltText: United States Capitol building at night
aboutCongress.title: What is Congress?

intro.paragraph_1: It is the legislative branch of the United States federal government. Put simply, it is responsible for making our nation's laws.
intro.paragraph_2: Interestingly, of the three main branches of our government, it is the only one that is elected directly by the American people. This gives us citizens a lot of power.

house.title: The House of Representatives
house.imageAltText: Seal of the United States House of Representatives

description.paragraph_1: In the House, each state has some representatives proportional to their population. The more people a state has, the more representatives it gets.
description.paragraph_2: Each representative serves a two year term. Because each term is so short, representatives are constantly considering the opinion of the people. If not, they would be voted out quickly.

powers.title: The House's special powers include:
powers.second: Deciding a presidential elections if there is a tie
powers.third: Any bills regarding taxes start in the House

senate.title: The Senate
senate.logo_alt_text: Seal of the United States Senate

description.paragraph_1: In the Senate, each state has the same number of senators, two. Therefore, each state is represented equally.
description.paragraph_2: Each senator serves a six year term. The reason for the longer terms, according to the founding fathers, was to allow the senators to debate and think through issues, without being too affected by swaying public opinion.

powers.title: The Senate's special powers include:
powers.third: Confirming special offices in the government like federal judges

twoParts.title: Why does Congress even have two parts?

description.paragraph_1: Well, the founding fathers were concerned that Congress would have too much power. So they split it up and made it so each part had power over the other.
description.paragraph_2: A bill (proposal for a law) can start in either the Senate or the House. In each case it is debated, revised, and debated some more. Once that is finished, it has to go through the same process in the other part of Congress. Because each part can check the other, neither gets too much power.
description.paragraph_3: Once both sides agree, you have a law!
